title: Parents blast NHS hospital over claims their stillborn baby was placed in a storage cupboard
text:
News Parents blast NHS hospital over claims their stillborn baby was placed in a storage cupboard His mother said she "screamed the place down" when medics were unable to find a heartbeat for baby Aaron Share By Annabel Howard Cathy Buss 10:14, 30 JAN 2017 Elaine Smith, 40, and her partner David Cameron, 42 (Photo: SWNS.com) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
A couple have made a formal complaint after claiming they found their stillborn baby had been placed in a hospital storage cupboard. 
Elaine Smith and partner David Cameron say they were also left distraught after finding out there was a delay of more than an hour before he was taken to the mortuary at Leicester Royal Infirmary . 
Baby Aaron was due on November 3 but on Tuesday, October 4, Elaine began feeling unwell. Unable to get a response from her community midwife she went to the infirmary's maternity assessment unit on Friday, October 7. 
The 40-year-old, from Saffron Lane, Leicester, told Leicester Mercury : "They couldn't find a heartbeat and I was told my baby had died. 
"I just screamed the place down. It was awful." Read More Incredible moment mother paralysed on hen do stands up and holds daughter for the first time 
The next day Elaine had to go through the agony of labour to have the baby she knew would be stillborn. 
"We were told that Aaron would be put on a special cold mat in a nursery specifically for 'sleeping' babies. 
"He was born at 9.26pm - it was absolutely horrible, horrendous, but Aaron still looked gorgeous." 
Elaine kept him with her until 1am when she asked if he could be put in the nursery. But, she asked for him back again at around 4am. 
She said: "When he was brought to me he wasn't cold. There was no-one with me, it was dreadful." 
Elaine asked for Aaron to be taken away again at 7.30am on the Sunday as partner David was coming in with their other young children. 
It was when David arrived and asked to see his son that he says he found him in his Moses basket in what Elaine described as a storage cupboard. 
She claimed: "It wasn't the special nursery which had been described to me." there was a delay of more than an hour before he was taken to the mortuary at Leicester Royal Infirmary 
David said: "I just picked Aaron up and sat on the floor crying." 
Later that day he went back to get Aaron as Elaine was due to be discharged home. Read More Twin girls born at just 23 WEEKS were so tiny they fitted in one hand - but look at them now 
Elaine claimed: "A midwife ushered him away and Aaron was brought to a delivery room so we could say goodbye. 
"Although we were given assurances he would be taken straight to the mortuary to be kept cold we found out later that the call wasn't made for another one-and-a-quarter hours. 
"Aaron was just not being looked after as he should have been." 
The couple say they suffered more agony with further delays before their baby was moved to a chapel of rest because the relevant paperwork had not been completed. 
They have put in a formal complaint to Leicester's hospitals which is still to be resolved. Read More Distraught mum asks whether baby name is inappropriate after gran says it brings up bad memories 
Elaine Broughton, head of midwifery at Leicester's hospitals, said: "We know Aaron's parents are grieving and my staff share their sorrow, stillbirth is a tragedy that affects all involved and our thoughts are with them. 
"When the parents called the community midwife she was in an antenatal clinic providing care for other mothers and hence the advice given on the recorded message is that parents should call the maternity assessment unit if they have any concerns whatsoever. In this case the parents didn't call the unit." 
She added: "When baby Aaron was stillborn he was placed in a special room on the delivery suite. 
"Aaron's parents felt it better for their other children if Aaron was not in this room when they visited." 
Ms Broughton said that once Aaron's parents had left to go home a midwife washed and wrapped the baby and completed the necessary paperwork for transfer to the mortuary. 
She added: "Done respectfully and properly this takes time." Like us on Facebook
